1038620252177948675.text:
On decision making—and key reason why startups can beat incumbents

IF there‘s a chain of command (+ path dependence) requiring serial consent: “Yes” > “yes” > “yes”—
—THEN a single “NO” kills a new idea

BUT if 19 VCs say no, 1 VC saying “yes” launches it.

Bezos nails it here:pic.twitter.com/Fi4cfX9pqu

I think we'll see the Augur/Veil two-step play out again & again:

Step 1: A permissionless financial protocol is created, but it's hard to use (Innovator stage)

Step 2: A centralized entity builds a UX on the protocol, smoothing edges & making it useful (Early Adopter stage)

The reality is, crypto is going to slowly creep into our lives. It'll be unnoticeable. It'll be inglorious. 

Be patient. Stop waiting for enlightenment.

1121521143079370762.text:
>> 
The current scalable solutions are lacking in many ways, but I believe they will keep improving, and that the many smart researchers currently working on scaling will eventually figure out excellent scalable ledgers. I don't think there is an inherent impossibility here.

1121520420799295490.text:
>>
The statement "blockchains can't scale" is still true today, but it's already possible to envision scalable solutions. Those are the multi-level chains: currently just L2, and eventually L1, L2, L3, etc. . Higher level -- lower throughput, higher security, higher importance
>>

1121519711211147264.text:
Sure, not all "miners" in the world will be in unified consensus on a single global state (that is indeed impossible to scale). But that is not needed. In reality, there will be a "soft consensus" on a distributed state, and that will suffice for scaling all applications.
>>

1121519408478851074.text:
Blockchains will eventually scale. I'm sure of it. All the intuition I gained from two decades of studying algorithms indicates that decentralized ledgers will eventually be able to scale, after research progresses enough.
>>https://twitter.com/muneeb/status/1121511731329679360 …

1090970550393077765.text: >> this makes me think there might be some inherent property or "truth" about complex systems, which causes such hierarchcal solutions to arise naturally as optimal solutions. Just as the math of special relativity follows from a few simple axioms, maybe hierarchcal courts do too

1090970498685648897.text: Interestingly, the hierarchical court system of mainchains-and-sidechains was not designed intending emulate the real world, but just arose naturally from cost-benefit analysis in bounded-throughput blockchains, i.e. from trying to use scarce expensive resources most frugally. >>

1090970430834442242.text: This beautifully mirrors real-world arbitration schemes, as well as new cryptoeconomic arbitration schemes (where the hierarchy of courts are made of people, not of blockchains).

1090970394067116032.text: I expect the same to hold in app-specific chains. The chain will be self-contained and self-running under normal circumstances. Cheating will escalate gradually through a "litigation hierarchy". Each level of the hierarchy will be more expensive to litigate in, but more secure

1090949055063183360.text: The point is that Web 3.0 will run on agreements signed off-chain. In normal circumstances, the network will just run and money will pay for service. If anyone tries to cheat, the matter gets gradually escalated. Only the final arbitrating contracts will be on the eth mainchain.

1090948530175393793.text:
This is the vision of most L2 solutions, as well as of Etheruem Swarm Team @ethswarm, with their "service agreement games".

1090946417017921536.text: These dedicated networks will still use the Ethereum mainnet to perform any major adjudication. The mainnet will be a "fallback of last resort", like a supreme court. 4/ I learned this pattern of argument from @albertwenger who claims that "privacy is a strategy, not a value".
Or in my formulation: privacy is a tool for obtaining freedom from oppression. Other tools for avoiding oppression exist & are sometimes betterhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lBUPEv6KlnM …

1088949564479021058.text: 3/ For more on the idea of decentralization as a tool for reducing friction (among other tools such as Zero Knowledge Proofs, SaaS, the legal system, and religion), all trying to increase collaboration and decrease friction, see my talk on CollabTech:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NPwtlsW8y6I …

1088948545124818946.text: 2/ But decentralization introduces other types of friction: UX friction; adoption friction; InfoSec friction. To minimize friction, we must pragmatically use technological tools depending on the use case. Decentralization is only one such tool.

1088948064331722752.text: 1/ Insight: Decentralization is a tool, not a goal. The true goal is reducing friction. Reliance on trusted central entities creates a lot of friction: compliance friction, accounting friction, legal friction, negotiation friction. Decentralization often reduces these frictions.

1088730909862477824.text: >> While Western Europe has a tradition of public media, and a relative willingness to fund it from taxpayers money, and to find ways to keep it independent. (Some countries do it better than ours). Maybe the US needs to finds a way to Europify its journalism.

1088730567183613952.text: >> (at least in western Europe, where judges are appointed by professional committees, not elected.) I suspect the wider story here is a Europe-vs-US story. The US lacks ways to publicly fund local journalism, and so has to rely on the free market. >>

1088730058095841280.text: >> But there's an anomaly here. Since journalism is a critical public good, why aren't we funding it collectively with tax dollars? >>
4. Defense: Free Range Algorithms live on a decentralized substrate where they are hard to stop. But not impossible. Here we defend from censorship attacks etc
5. C&C and strategy: coordinate modules 1-4 and optimize for the goal function. (Survival? Paper clip maximization?)

1085528990620835845.text:
And some newer insights:
A free range algorithm consists of the following modules:
1. Economic incentives -- to incentivize humans to help it
2. AI modules: who needs humans anyhow?
3. Procreation/Mutation -- Darwinistic spawning of offspring and seeing which survive
>>

1081705079151968258.text: Plus, of course, @mekkaokereke's actual point: that talent is equally distributed, but opportunity is not. We need to make sure that folks from all geographies, races, genders, get the opportunity to shine. This means that VCs (and all others) have to look outside the spotlight.

1081705077902069760.text: This is one of the least appreciated facts about startups: the main role of the CEO is to be the public face of the company, the ecosystem builder, the fundraiser. The rest of the team are the ones that do the building. In many ways, the CEO is the actual "support role".

1080634231678795776.text: 5/5 Arguably this illiquid investing game is a human game in the best of ways: It encourages partnerships between people. This can be aided by data, but ultimately it's about building positive-sum collaborations to create new technology. I find this incredibly satisfying.

1080634061968822273.text: 4/  Poetically, illiquidity makes VC more human in other ways: By preventing counterfactual analysis, reduced data availability prevents automation. The long-term lock-in makes ROI depend on the person of the investor, which doesn't normally happen in public markets.

1080633588104814594.text: 3/ Illiquidity far better aligns our interests with a startup's long-term success than for a normal stock-holder, and sets this game as far more human-based.

1080633420282294273.text: 2/ Illiquidity is key. My partner @shemtovo likes to say 'illiquidity is a feature, not a bug'. Non-liquid investments force long-term commitments to startups and founders.

1080632842898554881.text: 1/ Agreed: the barriers to systematic VC are lack of data and lack of tradability. Indeed if we imagine changing the VC game so that data is fully available and secondaries are completely liquid, then we get the normal stock market, plus some barriers to entry.https://twitter.com/philippvdk/status/1080568545757413376 …

1080287273843871744.text: Crypto winter will be a Darwinian extinction event, and only the fittest will survive. This great post analyzes the fascinating @mattereum project. It explains how Mattereum might change the world, why we need a system like it, how it is positioned to survive crypto winter.https://twitter.com/hackernoon/status/1080094295456018432 …

1080271726758514689.text:
While science expands into VC, VC will expand into CPG:
Caldbeck claims that VC-style investing is ripe to make a big impact on CPG.
He says the biggest barrier is VC financial engineering: finding the right business model for a VC to do profitable investing in CPG. Fascinating!https://twitter.com/ryan_caldbeck/status/974045873377239040 …

1080267982121648129.text: 13/13 To summarize: Yes, over the coming years VCs will become more scientific, more data-based, and less subject to human biases. No, this revolution will not look the same as it did in Wall Street.

1080267980431331328.text: 12/ In general, I think we'll see VCs adopt more academically-inspired processes. Some academic processes that might be good inspiration: the building of scientific consensus, the hiring process and building of academic faculties; the PhD system.

1080267978959134720.text: 11/  Second, we will see a more peer-review-type processes among VCs. (E.g. where founders get asked to rate other founders.)

1080267977851838464.text: 10/ Thus, I suspect that the impact of scientifically-inspired methods will manifest very differently in VC than in Wall Street. One impact: VCs will reinforce the importance of skepticism, divergent opinions and a contrarian mindset (already happening).

1080267976685821952.text: 9/ In other words: while the stock market is relatively information-symmetric, transparent and highly liquid, the VC market is characterized by high information-asymmetry, opaqueness and very low liquidity.

1080267975456972800.text: 8/ Also, in stock markets, time periods are shorter. For example, high-frequency trading, the field where quants have the most control, has trade times of seconds or less. In contrast, VC takes at least a few years to measure results, with little access to counterfactuals.

1080267973812727808.text: 7/ In particular, in highly-liquid markets such as stock markets you always know counterfactuals: "what would have happened if I didn't make this investment?". This allows you to back-test.

1080267972286038022.text: 6/ It happened in Wall Street, but stock trading has certain features that makes it very "automatable" and subject to rigorous quantitative analysis.

1080267970742550528.text:
5/ But some other aspects of scouting and picking are hard to improve scientifically, and will be left in the hands of humans for many years.
Will we have a systematic early-stage VC, where many decisions are made without a human in the loop? I'm guessing not for decades.

1080267969438064647.text: 4/ These are the aspects where scientifically-trained personnel will improve VC. I think that some particular aspects of scouting and picking do have this property, and they do stand to greatly improve with more evidence-based tools.

1080267968091734016.text: 3/ These scientifically-inspired approaches will revolutionize VC, but it won't necessarily look like the Quants' takeover. To figure out how a scientifically-inspired revolution in VC will look, consider the aspects of VC that are least objective and most subject to human biases

1080266527872552965.text: 2/ I think the lesson from the quants' takeover is that scientifically-inspired, evidence-based, meticulously self-criticized and peer-reviewed techniques are the key to improved success in *any* field.

1080266213803069440.text:
1/ I think VC-space is learning the wrong lesson from the Quants' conquest of Wall Street.
Many draw the lesson that quants will also conquer VC, with the same technical and analytical skills that they used to revolutionize stock-trading practices.
I disagree.
(Thread )https://twitter.com/ryan_caldbeck/status/1050053368641703937 …

1074029427779141635.text: "Investors" are an abstraction of a type of stakeholders, but it might be an outdated abstraction. If you think of it, even VCs don't believe in investors as a pure abstraction -- that's why they always talk about "added value", "smart vs dumb money" and "choosing investors". >>

1074028817595936774.text: I think the biggest insight for me is to stop thinking of tokens as "a different type of equity", just like cars are not "a different type of horse". Cryptoeconomic systems can align incentives in a more general way, between all kinds of stakeholders. >>

1073215446608986112.text: The problem is that in the Blockchain community the differences between technical decetralization and other forms of decentralization are not cleanly delimited. There's a mix between "ought" and "is". Vitalik wrote a great post about this a while back:https://medium.com/@VitalikButerin/the-meaning-of-decentralization-a0c92b76a274 …

1073214872119402496.text: Very important observation. Basically, DLTs solve a *technical* decentralization problem: how to make a service/SaaS that cannot be technically controlled by one party. But DLTs do not solve governance decentralization: i.e. how to make good collective decision making. >>https://twitter.com/TatianaCutts/status/1073163827812990976 …

1055433180227035136.text: >> i.e. who pays for CPU cycles (everyone, via inflation? the caller, via fees?), who pays for storage (one-time fee? recurring rent-like fees?) who pays for network transportation? Do all miners keep all storage? etc etc

1055432682652532746.text:
This is related to an insight from @thomasfuerstner :
Many "Turing-Complete" blockchain systems are more or less computationally equivalent: they all can roughly simulate a computer. But the big differences between them is in "who does what and who pays for it" >>

1055404821610663937.text:
2/2 In contrast, in a traditional programming language it's easy: you have one computer and that computer does everything.

Thus, the design space of decentralized languages is potentially much larger than that of "standard" programming languages.

1055404653737852928.text:
1/ Obvious (?) insight:
A programming language for decentralized systems (eg solidity) needs to capture not only what computation is performed and how it is performed, but also *who does what*. Who stores the data, who performs each part of the computation, and so on.

We're approaching an age of Free-Range Algorithms

>> Thus, consumer is incentivized to share their data liberally. E.g. can advertise to consumers based on their entire browser history, while keeping it private.
This is an example of why ZK/SMPC is actually CollaborationTech: if privacy is assured, all parties will share *more*.

1013569067985309702.text: >> publisher gets paid. Consumer gets kickback for sharing more-private data. The matching is done using SMPC: so advertiser and publisher do not learn which consumers got targeted, and so the consumer's data remains entirely private >>
